newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-ORIOLES SNAP LOSING STREAK AGAINST WHITE SOX.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-ORIOLES SNAP LOSING STREAK AGAINST WHITE SOX.

text.p: Chris Hoiles snapped a tie with a two-run homer in the sixth inning, and the Baltimore Orioles' bullpen shut down the Chicago White Sox for an 8-3 victory to snap a three-game losing streak on Saturday.
Hoiles added an RBI double and Rafael Palmeiro and Jeffrey Hammonds also homered for the Orioles, who won for just the third time in their last 12 games.

"It was a strange game," said Orioles manager Davey Johnson, who held a closed-door meeting before the game. "Raffy got a big hit and we hung in 'til Hoiles' hit. I was looking for a win any way we could get it."
"Davey didn't say much of anything, but anytime the manager talks with the team, it helps," Hoiles said.
Chicago's bullpen allowed five runs after permitting just two earned runs in its previous 32 innings over 10 games.
In Cleveland, Jeff Suppan allowed a run over six innings, and John Valentin blasted two solo homers to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 6-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
Suppan (4-0) scattered five hits and one walk with two strikeouts.

"Today I was changing speeds on the fastball," said Suppan. "I threw a few changeups and sliders. I was getting groundball outs and I just wanted to get outs early in the count instead of going deep."
Wil Cordero added a three-run double in the third for Boston, which has won the first four games of its six-game road trip.
In Milwaukee, David Wells tossed a three-hitter for his 100th career win and Paul O'Neill had four hits and four RBI as the New York Yankees routed the Milwaukee Brewers, 8-0.
Wells (10-4) struck out four without walking a batter for his first shutout of the season and 14th of his career.
Kelly led off the third inning by sending an 0-1 pitch over the left-field fence to give the Yankees a 3-0 lead.

In Oakland, Chuck Knoblauch had three hits and Paul Molitor delivered a two-run double to cap a four-run seventh inning and lead the Minnesota Twins to their third straight victory, 7-6 over the Oakland Athletics.
Knoblauch had a double and two singles, while Molitor, who missed two games with an abdominal strain, got the last of five straight hits in the seventh to give the Twins a 6-3 advantage.
"Molitor's ball really hurt us," Oakland manager Art Howe said. "We had two strikes on him and he ended up hitting a ball off the wall. The seventh inning got us."
At Texas, Brian Hunter's single with one out in the top of the eighth inning scored Matt Walbeck with the go-ahead run and lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 6-5 victory over the Texas Rangers.

Reliever Xavier Hernandez (0-4) got Damion Easley to ground out to start the eighth. Walbeck walked and Deivi Cruz singled him to third. Hunter then laced a single up the middle to put the Tigers ahead.

In Anaheim, Tony Phillips' two-out single in the bottom of the ninth inning scored Luis Alicea with the winning run, giving the Anaheim Angels their 11th win in 12 games, 5-4 over the Toronto Blue Jays.

With one out in the ninth, Alicea drew a walk off Mike Timlin (2-2), who struck out pinch-hitter Jack Howell. But Alicea stole second before Phillips grounded a 3-2 pitch between shortstop and third base to score Alicea.

In Seattle, Craig Paquette's RBI single snapped a tie and highlighted a four-run ninth inning as the Kansas City Royals overcame a six-run deficit to stop a 12-game road losing streak with a 9-6 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

With one out in the ninth, Tom Goodwin blooped a single to left field off Seattle closer Bobby Ayala (6-4). Jay Bell's single moved Goodwin to second and Chili Davis walked before Jeff King's sacrifice fly tied the game, 6-6. Paquette lined the first pitch he saw into right-centre, scoring Bell to put the Royals ahead for good.
Shane Halter followed with his first career double, scoring pinch-runner Ryan Long and Paquette with Kansas City's final runs.
